The_Quebe_Sisters:
{{Short description|American swing revival band}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = The Quebe Sisters | image = Quebe Sisters band at Alamodome, San Antonio, TX IMG 7614.JPG | caption = Quebe Sisters band at Alamodome, San Antonio, TX | background = group_or_band | alias = The Quebe Sisters Band | genre = {{Flatlist| *[[Western swing]] *[[jazz]] *[[Swing music|swing]] *[[Country music|country]] }} | years_active = [[2000 in music|2000]]—present | label = | website = [http://www.quebesisters.com www.quebesisters.com] | current_members = Grace Quebe
Sophia Quebe
Hulda Quebe
Simon Stipp
Daniel Parr | past_members = Mark Abbott, Drew Phelps, Joey McKenzie, Gavin Kelso, Penny Clark, Katy Clark| }} [[File:The Quebe Sisters Band (4854598924).jpg|thumb|The Quebe Sisters Band (4854598924)]] '''The Quebe Sisters''' are an American [[swing revival]] band based in [[Dallas|Dallas, Texas]], who perform a mix of progressive [[western swing]], jazz-influenced swing, [[Country music|country]], Texas-style fiddling, and [[Western music (North America)|western music]]. The band consists of sisters Grace, Sophia, and Hulda Quebe, all of whom play the fiddle and sing, with supporting musicians accompanying on guitar, upright bass, or other instruments. ==Origins== Grace Quebe, Sophia Quebe, and Hulda Quebe (pronounced ''kway-bee'') grew up in North Texas.Dave Ferman, [https://poststar.com/lifestyles/sisters-find-their-calling-in-old-time-fiddle-music/article_48489506-b897-587e-8069-18bbc8b76694.html, "Sisters find their calling in old-time fiddle music"], The Post-Star, 22 July 2003, retrieved 9 May 2018 After briefly studying classical violin, in 1998 the sisters switched to fiddle when they attended the [[North Texas State Fair and Rodeo|North Texas State Fair]] in [[Denton, Texas]]. There they first heard Texas-style fiddling, and afterwards met Joey and Sherry McKenzie, national fiddle champions and founders of the Bob Wills Fiddle Festival & Contest in [[Greenville, Texas]]. Soon after, the sisters became students of the McKenzies,Jesse Mullins, Jr., [https://books.google.com/books?id=eOoCAAAAMBAJ, "Throwbacks and Naturals"], American Cowboy, Oct-Nov 2014, p.20, retrieved 8 May 2018 and the Quebe family moved to [[Burleson, Texas]] in [[Tarrant County, Texas|Tarrant County]]. The sisters studied with the McKenzies for several years and Joey McKenzie became their arranger and a longtime member of their band. ==Early career== One of the sisters' first paying gigs was in 2000, when [[Red Steagall]] heard and invited them to perform at The Red Steagall Cowboy Gathering and [[Western Swing]] Festival in the Fort Worth Stockyards, a festival to which they returned to perform for 13 years straight. Entering fiddle contests, they had success early on, winning several state, regional, and national fiddle championships.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/20/AR2006092001861.html|title=The Quebe Sisters' Arresting Swing Harmonies|first=Chris|last=Richards|date=21 September 2006|publisher=|via=washingtonpost.com}} In their respective age groups Sophia Quebe was Texas State champion in 1999 and 2000, Hulda Quebe was Texas State champion in 2000 and 2001, and Grace Quebe was Texas State champion in 2001. Then in 2002, at the National Oldtime Fiddler's Contest in Weiser, ID, oldest sister Grace took first place in the junior division with middle sister Sophia placing second and youngest sister Hulda winning the junior-junior title. In 2003 they released their first album, ''Texas Fiddlers'', backed by Joey McKenzie on rhythm guitar, Mark Abbott on bass, and others, including steel guitarist Tom Morrell. Recorded locally in Burleson, Texas, the all-instrumental album featured Texas-style fiddling and western swing tunes. Also in 2003, after hearing them perform backstage at [[Bass Performance Hall]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], [[Ricky Skaggs]] invited them onstage during his show, where they played the western swing standard "San Antonio Rose." Afterwards he invited them to perform on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] for the first time. Since then they have appeared on the Opry and at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] numerous times. The sisters began touring outside their home region of [[Texas]] and [[Oklahoma]] in 2004, including performing at the [[National Folk Festival (United States)|National Folk Festival]], then held in [[Bangor, Maine]], a festival to which they returned in 2007.[http://www.americanfolkfestival.com/assets/aff-performers-2002-2015.pdf, "Cumulative list of Folk Festival performers in Bangor from 2002-2015"], retrieved 8 May 2018 Also in 2004 they were featured on episode 891 of [[Bob Phillips]]' ''[[Texas Country Reporter]]'' [[anthology series|anthology]] [[television series]].{{cite web |url=http://texascountryreporter.com/episodes/episodes-2004 |title=Episodes 2004 | Texas Country Reporter |website=texascountryreporter.com |access-date=18 May 2018}} In early 2005 the sisters met Ray Benson of [[Asleep at the Wheel]] who was working on a musical about the life of [[Bob Wills]] called "A Ride with Bob."[https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/63899/benson-asleep-at-the-wheel-take-a-ride-with-bob, Billboard, 2 March 2005, "Benson & Asleep At The Wheel Take 'A Ride With Bob'"], retrieved 8 May 2018 Benson invited them to be a part of the production, and their appearances included the shows in [[Austin, Texas]] celebrating Bob Wills’s 100th birthday, and a weekend in September 2006 at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]] with President [[George W. Bush]] and First Lady [[Laura Bush]] in attendance.Celia Wren, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/24/AR2006092401110.html, The Washington Post, 25 September 2006, "'A Ride With Bob,' and George"], retrieved 8 May 2018 ==Career highlights== In 2007 The Quebe Sisters performed with [[Warren Buffett]] on ukulele singing "Red River Valley" at the [[Berkshire Hathaway|Berkshire-Hathaway]] Annual Shareholders Meeting in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], at the invitation of the [[Justin Brands]] western footwear company.[https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070505005009/en/Warren-Buffett-Performed-Justin-Brands-Booth, Business Wire, 5 May 2007, "Warren Buffett Performed at Justin Brands Booth"], retrieved 8 May 2018 That year they also recorded their second album, ''Timeless'', which was recorded at Cash Cabin Studio in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]], where [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter Cash]] made their later recordings. Invited by the Cash family to record there, the sisters capitalized on the opportunity to make their vocal debut album arranged and produced by Joey McKenzie. Inspired by the vocal stylings of the [[Mills Brothers]], ''Timeless'' featured the sisters' three-part harmony vocals and included songs from the [[Sons of the Pioneers]], Bob Wills & The Texas Playboys, [[Spade Cooley]], and [[Duke Ellington]]. In 2009 The Quebe Sisters appeared on Episode 26 of The Marty Stuart Show together with The Opry Square Dancers, [[Connie Smith]], [[Leroy Troy]] and The Tennessee Mafia Jug Band, and The Fabulous Superlatives.{{Cite web|url=http://www.martystuart.com/mss-4-25-09.htm,|title=martystuart.com, retrieved 9 May 2018}} That year, the Quebes met twin sisters Penny and Katy Clark backstage at the Grand Ole Opry. After learning that they were fellow Texans, the girls became fast friends and later toured together in 2014 before the Clarks left to continue their own group, The Purple Hulls.{{Cite web|url=https://thepurplehulls.com/,|title=The Purple Hulls website}} Over the years the band has toured extensively in [[Canada]], and in 2010 the sisters toured in Europe, appearing at events including the [[Cambridge Folk Festival]] in England[https://www.cambridgelivetrust.co.uk/folk-festival/folk-festival/history/2006-2010, Cambridge Live] and the Festival Country Rendez-Vous in [[Craponne-sur-Arzon|Craponne sur Arzon, France]].CultureBox, [https://culturebox.francetvinfo.fr/musique/le-festival-de-musique-country-rendez-vous-2010musique-au-champ-a-craponne-sur-arzon-36397, France.tv, 26 July 2010, retrieved 9 May 2018] On November 20, 2010 they were guest performers on [[A Prairie Home Companion]] at The Brown Theater in [[Houston|Houston, Texas]].[https://www.prairiehome.org/shows/56627.html, 20 November 2010, "November 20, 2010 broadcast with The Quebe Sisters Band, Richard Kriehn, and Susan Graham"], retrieved 8 May 2018 The same year they appeared on episode 571 of the ''[[WoodSongs Old-Time Radio Hour]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.woodsongs.com/show-archives/, |title=WoodSongs Show Archives |website=www.woodsongs.com |access-date=18 May 2018}} In 2012 The Quebe Sisters performed [[Connie Smith]]'s 1964 debut hit "Once a Day" at Smith's induction into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]].Stephen L. Betts, [http://theboot.com/country-music-hall-of-fame-inductions-garth-brooks/, The Boot, 22 October 2012], retrieved 8 May 2018 The same year, they appeared on [[NPR]]'s [[Mountain Stage]].[https://www.npr.org/2012/09/20/161473413/the-quebe-sisters-band-on-mountain-stage, "The Quebe Sisters Band On Mountain Stage", NPR website, 28 February 2013], retrieved 18 May 2018 In March 2013 The Quebe Sisters toured in [[Russia]], including a performance at [[Spaso House]], the U.S. Embassy.Stephen L. Betts, [https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/texas-swing-takes-on-russia-22574, "Texas Swing Takes On Russia," The Moscow Times, 22 March 2013], retrieved 15 May 2018 On March 30, 2013 The Quebe Sisters performed with the [[Dallas Symphony Orchestra]] at the [[Meyerson Symphony Center]] in Dallas, TX{{Cite web|url=https://www.last.fm/event/3252849+DSO+Pops+Series:+Quebe+Sisters+Band|title=DSO Pops Series: Quebe Sisters Band at Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center (Dallas) on 30 Mar 2013|website=Last.fm}} and again on May 29, 2014 at [[Klyde Warren Park]] in [[Downtown Dallas]].{{Cite web|url=https://dallas.culturemap.com/eventdetail/quebe-sisters-band-dallas-symphony-orchestra/|title=Quebe Sisters Band with the Dallas Symphony Orchestra - CultureMap Dallas|website=dallas.culturemap.com}} In 2014 the sisters released their third album, ''Every Which-A-Way''. Recorded at Allegro Sound Lab in Burleson, Texas and produced by Joey McKenzie, it showed a further evolution of the band's reach into a variety of styles, hitting #38 on [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'s Jazz Albums chart on March 1.{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/the-quebe-sisters-band,|title=Billboard}} In 2015 The Quebe Sisters and [[Willie Nelson]] contributed a track ("Along the Navajo Trail") to the album "Still the King: Celebrating the Music of Bob Wills and His Texas Playboys," a tribute album put together by Asleep at the Wheel. The following year the sisters, along with [[The Avett Brothers]] and [[Amos Lee]], both of whom had also contributed to the album, appeared with Asleep at the Wheel on ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' in a special tribute to Wills.{{Cite web|url=http://acltv.com/mentioned-artist/quebe-sisters/,|title=Austin City Limits website}} On August 18, 2015 the sisters performed in [[New York City]] with [[Sam Outlaw]] at a Roots of American Music/Americanafest NYC concert at [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]].Hank S., [https://www.timeout.com/newyork/blog/heres-the-full-2015-lincoln-center-out-of-doors-lineup-050715, Time Out New York, 7 May 2015, "Here's the full 2015 Lincoln Center Out of Doors lineup"], retrieved 9 May 2018 On September 16, 2015, [[Amos Lee]] featured The Quebe Sisters as guests on episode 3, season 5 of the PBS program ''[[Bluegrass Underground]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/the-caverns-sessions/episodes-season-5/1000485345/|title=The Caverns Sessions|website=TVGuide.com}} On Nov 11, 2015 episode 11, season 5 of the PBS program [[Bluegrass Underground]] aired, featuring The Quebe Sisters accompanied by Penny Clark, Katy Clark, and Drew Phelps. On November 28, 2016, The Quebe Sisters were featured guest artists of [[Kacey Musgraves]] on the CMA Christmas Special.Lauren Tingle, [https://web.archive.org/web/20161126162007/http://www.cmt.com/news/1773841/kacey-musgraves-readies-a-very-kacey-christmas-tour/ CMT News, 25 November 2016, "Kacey Musgraves Readies A Very Kacey Christmas Tour"], retrieved 15 May 2018 The sisters have performed with [[Merle Haggard]], [[George Strait]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]], [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], [[Connie Smith]], [[Marty Stuart]], [[Ricky Skaggs]] & [[Kentucky Thunder]], [[Riders in the Sky (band)|Riders in the Sky]], [[Amos Lee]], [[Delbert McClinton]], [[Band of Heathens]], [[Larry Gatlin]] & [[The Gatlin Brothers]], [[Asleep at the Wheel]], [[Kacey Musgraves]], and [[Dailey & Vincent]] among others. They've been featured performers at the [[Stagecoach Festival]], Ernest Tubb Midnight Jamboree, [[Smithsonian Folklife Festival]], [[MerleFest]], the [[Philadelphia Folk Festival]], Pickathon, and the [[Cavendish Beach Music Festival]]. == Discography == The Quebe Sisters Discography * ''Texas Fiddlers'' (2003) * ''Timeless'' (2007) * ''Every Which-A-Way'' (2014) * ''The Quebe Sisters'' (2019) === Collaborations === * ''Vice and Virtue'' by Jimmy Needham (2015) (featured on the track Sirens) * ''Still the King: Celebrating the Music of Bob Wills and His Texas Playboys'' (2015) (featured on the track "Along the Navajo Trail" with [[Willie Nelson]]) * ''[[A Very Kacey Christmas]]'' (2016) (contributed to tracks on [[Kacey Musgraves]]' Christmas album) * ''Justin Trevino & The Quebe Sisters'' (2017) (featured on the tracks "Blue Bonnet Lane" and "The Son Shines Down On Me") == Sources == {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quebe Sisters}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 2000]] [[Category:Swing revival ensembles]] [[Category:Western swing musical groups]] [[Category:Country music groups from Texas]] [[Category:Musical groups from Dallas]] [[Category:People from Burleson, Texas]] [[Category:2000 establishments in Texas]]
